body:
Hi Daniel,

Thanks for your bug report. I was able to fix the bug. I will release a new plug-in version today and reply here once it is out.

I was able to configure the Shared Credentials with the git repository a alternative. Looking at source code for the project tests I found this piece of code:

https://github.com/mibexsoftware/bamboo-plan-dsl-plugin/blob/master/src/test/groovy/ch/mibex/bamboo/plandsl/dsl/scm/ScmsSpec.groovy#L92

``` groovy
authType: new SharedCredentialsAuth(SharedCredentialsAuth.SharedCredentialsType.USERNAMEPW, 'sharedpw')
```

By seeing this I set my git scm DSL like this and it worked fine for me:

``` groovy
scm {
    git('PAGU') {
        url 'git@git.company.com.br:group/product.git'
        branch 'develop'
        authType: new SharedCredentialsAuth(SharedCredentialsAuth.SharedCredentialsType.SSH, 'gitlab')
    }
}
```

Hi Tiago,

Thanks for reporting this. Unfortunately, I wasn't able to reproduce this error. Could you please give me the full stack trace? Also, which version of the plug-in are you using?

@mrueegg,

My versions are:
- Bamboo: 5.13.2
- Plan DSL plug-in for Bamboo: 1.2.0

And this is the full stack trace:


Fixed with release 1.2.1. Thanks for reporting this bug!
Fixed with release 1.2.1. Thanks for reporting this bug!
Fixed with release 1.2.1. Thanks for reporting this bug!

Inspecting the http request in the browser and using the documentation for [bamboo taks](https://github.com/mibexsoftware/bamboo-plan-dsl-plugin/wiki/Bamboo-tasks), I was able to do a workaround.

Http Request Form Data:
![devinspect-injectbamboovariables](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/144190/19777992/1d89fa60-9c51-11e6-9b3f-ab2ab0ff2a40.PNG)

DSL Definition:

``` groovy
custom('com.atlassian.bamboo.plugins.bamboo-variable-inject-plugin:inject') {
    isFinal true
    description "Inject Build Variables"
    configure(
            filePath: 'envVars.properties',
            namespace: 'soulmv',
            scope: InjectBambooVariablesTask.VariablesScope.RESULT
    )
}
```

Implemented with version 1.4.0. Thanks for reporting this!
Fixed with version 1.4.0. Thanks for reporting this!
Hey thanks for the quick update! It does help. Would the code be different if you need to download an artifact produced by a job in another plan?

Hi,

Thanks for your example DSL. With it, I was able to reproduce this problem. Artifact downloading in a plan from a different stage currently results in this bug. 

I've fixed this now and will spin a new release tomorrow. This new release will also support artifact downloading from different plans. We will introduce a new field `sourcePlanKey` in the downloader task so that you can specify a different plan to download your artifact from.

I'll reply here once the new release is available in the Marketplace.

This is correct, we currently do not delete plans, jobs, stages and deployment projects if they are not in the DSL script (anymore). I think before we can do this, we need to make this explicit to the user with a configurable option, something like this:

"Action for removed entities":

- Ignore
- Disable
- Delete

where _Ignore_ should probably be the default. What do you think?

I talked with some of my colleagues about this, and we are of the opinion that the codebase should never be able to have a different state than what is deployed to bamboo. You can have it configurable, however it makes it so that by default your code and service could diverge.

So I'm more of the opinion that it should at least default to delete if you want it configurable. I appreciate you asking for my input :)
Fixed with release 1.4.1. This release also contains the new `sourcePlanKey` field. Please update your plug-in installation and try again.

We're also looking forward to have this feature implemented. I'd expect that if I remove a task, job or stage definition from DSL they should also be removed from Bamboo. However, it should **not** be possible to remove plans and projects via DSL (without an explicit setting). 

Reason is - removed tasks, jobs or stages can be easily recreated (from previous revision of DSL or manually) and the impact of such change is low. However, if you remove a project or plan you also lose all build history, logs and artifacts!

Implementing it the way I suggest will protect users from accidentaly deleting plans and still enable them to have plans fully configurable via DSL.
@grdl Thanks for your feedback. I agree with your points. We will try to provide this feature with the next release of the plug-in.
Hey I also agree that its probably best to not remove the plans or projects unless you specifically say so. Thanks!
Thanks @mrueegg ! I'll up with the latest release soon and try again.
